paper_title: Accuracy is Not All You Need
paper_content: This paper argues that evaluating compressed large language models (LLMs) solely based on accuracy is insufficient.  It demonstrates that while compressed models can maintain similar accuracy metrics to baselines, they exhibit significant discrepancies in answers, termed "flips."  The authors propose that distance metrics like KL-divergence and the percentage of flips provide more comprehensive evaluations of compressed models, especially in free-form generation tasks.

paper_title: Agnostic Learning of Mixed Linear Regressions with EM and AM Algorithms
paper_content: This paper investigates the agnostic learning of mixed linear regressions using the expectation maximization (EM) and alternating minimization (AM) algorithms.  It demonstrates that, under specific conditions of separability and appropriate initialization, these algorithms converge to the population loss minimizers,  even without a generative model for the data.  This extends previous analyses which relied on generative models.

paper_title: Asymptotically Optimal and Computationally Efficient Average Treatment Effect Estimation in A/B testing
paper_content: This paper aims to develop asymptotically optimal and computationally efficient policies for estimating the average treatment effect (ATE) in A/B testing.  It establishes a lower bound on the expected sample size for any adaptive policy achieving a desired confidence interval (CI) width and probability of not containing the true ATE.  The paper then proposes two adaptive policies, one computationally intensive but asymptotically optimal and another computationally efficient while maintaining asymptotic optimality, showing they perform comparably in practice.

paper_title: AutoMix: Automatically Mixing Language Models

author_list.affiliation_name: School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University
author_list.name: Pranjal Aggarwal

author_list.affiliation_name: School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University

paper_content: The paper introduces AutoMix, a method for automatically selecting the optimal language model (LM) size for a given query.  AutoMix leverages a few-shot self-verification mechanism within a smaller LM to estimate query difficulty, and then uses a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) router to efficiently route queries to larger models when necessary, thereby optimizing computational cost while maintaining performance.  Experiments on diverse language models and datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AutoMix compared to existing methods.

paper_title: BRAIn: Bayesian Reward-conditioned Amortized Inference for natural language generation from feedback
paper_content: This paper introduces BRAIN, a novel reinforcement learning method for aligning large language models (LLMs) with human feedback.  BRAIN leverages Bayesian inference to define a reward-conditioned posterior distribution as the target distribution for distribution-matching methods.  Critically, it also introduces a self-normalized baseline to significantly reduce gradient estimation variance, resulting in improved performance on summarization and Antropic HH tasks compared to prior state-of-the-art methods.

paper_title: COLD: Causal reasOning in cLosed Daily activities
paper_content: This paper introduces COLD, a framework for evaluating large language models' (LLMs) causal reasoning abilities.  COLD uses real-world daily activities as a basis for causal queries, aiming to bridge the gap between theoretical and real-world grounding.  The authors create a large dataset of causal queries to comprehensively evaluate LLMs on their understanding of causal relationships in everyday tasks.

paper_title: Causal Discovery with Fewer Conditional Independence Tests

author_list.affiliation_name: Electrical Engineering & Computer Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

paper_content: This paper introduces a new algorithm for causal discovery that significantly reduces the number of conditional independence (CI) tests required compared to existing methods.  The algorithm learns a "Causal Consistent Partition Graph" (CCPG) representation of the causal graph in polynomial time.  This representation efficiently captures the causal relationships, enabling recovery of the true causal graph when it's identifiable through observational data or with interventions.

paper_title: Centralized Selection with Preferences in the Presence of Biases
paper_content: This paper addresses the problem of centralized candidate selection for multiple institutions, considering biases in candidate utilities.  It introduces an algorithm, Ainst-wise, designed to maximize true utility while ensuring fairness in preference and representation for disadvantaged groups.  The algorithm achieves near-optimal fairness and utility under distributional assumptions.

paper_title: Conformal Prediction for Class-wise Coverage via Augmented Label Rank Calibration
paper_content: This paper introduces Rank Calibrated Class-conditional Conformal Prediction (RC3P), an algorithm for class-wise coverage in conformal prediction.  RC3P aims to reduce prediction set sizes while maintaining valid coverage for each class in classification tasks with many and/or imbalanced categories.  The method selectively applies a class-wise thresholding subroutine based on the classifier's confidence in the predicted labels, leading to smaller prediction sets compared to standard class-conditional CP.

paper_title: Detecting and Measuring Confounding Using Causal Mechanism Shifts

author_list.affiliation_name: CISPA Helmholtz Center for Information Security
author_list.name: Abbavaram Gowtham Reddy

paper_content: This paper aims to develop a comprehensive approach for detecting and measuring confounding effects in observational data.  It seeks to relax assumptions of causal sufficiency and parametric assumptions, leveraging advancements in causal discovery and confounding analysis with non-i.i.d. data.  The approach will consider various confounding definitions and introduce tailored methodologies to measure confounding, differentiate between observed and unobserved confounding, and assess the relative strengths of confounding bias between variable sets.

paper_title: DisCEdit: Model Editing by Identifying Discriminative Components

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Science, Indian institute of science, Bangalore
author_list.name: Chiranjib Bhattacharyya

paper_content: This paper introduces DISCEDIT, a method for model editing that identifies discriminative components within neural networks.  DISCEDIT utilizes a novel, distribution-agnostic approach to quantify discriminative ability, enabling algorithms for structured pruning and selective forgetting without requiring access to training data or loss functions.  The method relies on lower bounds on Total Variation distance, and achieves state-of-the-art results on datasets like CIFAR10 and ImageNet.

paper_title: Enhancing Trajectory Prediction through Self-Supervised Waypoint Distortion Prediction
paper_content: This paper proposes a novel self-supervised learning approach, SSWDP, to enhance trajectory prediction models.  SSWDP predicts distortions in observed trajectories as a pretext task, improving representation learning and subsequent future trajectory predictions.  The method outperforms baseline approaches on various datasets, including NBA, TrajNet++, and ETH-UCY, demonstrating significant accuracy gains especially in distorted environments.

paper_title: FUGAL: Feature-fortified Unrestricted Graph Alignment
paper_content: The paper introduces FUGAL, a novel graph alignment method.  FUGAL directly aligns graph adjacency matrices, avoiding the intermediary representations used in existing methods.  It aims to improve alignment accuracy compared to prior state-of-the-art methods while maintaining computational efficiency.

paper_title: FactorSim: Generative Simulation via Factorized Representation
paper_content: The paper introduces FACTORSIM, a framework for generating coded simulations from natural language input.  FACTORSIM utilizes a factored POMDP representation to decompose the generation process into manageable steps, thus mitigating context dependence issues typical in large language models.  The framework is evaluated on a novel benchmark assessing generated simulation accuracy and zero-shot transfer capabilities in reinforcement learning, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing methods.

paper_title: Finite Time Logarithmic Regret Bounds for Self-Tuning Regulation

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Science, Indian institute of science, Bangalore
author_list.name: Avik Kar

paper_content: This paper establishes novel finite-time logarithmic regret bounds for the self-tuning regulation problem, a critical control problem with numerous engineering applications.  It introduces a modified certainty equivalence algorithm, PIECE, incorporating input clipping and probing for exploration.  The proposed algorithm achieves a logarithmic regret bound, a significant improvement over existing results for similar linear quadratic control problems, which typically exhibit a polynomial regret bound.

paper_title: Generalized Linear Bandits with Limited Adaptivity

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Science, Indian institute of science, Bangalore
author_list.name: Nirjhar Das

paper_content: This paper addresses the generalized linear contextual bandit problem with limited adaptivity.  It proposes two algorithms, B-GLinCB and RS-GLinCB, to handle different scenarios of policy update constraints.  The algorithms aim to minimize regret while updating their policy only a limited number of times, achieving optimal guarantees without dependence on an instance-specific parameter related to model non-linearity.

paper_title: Graph Edit Distance with General Costs Using Neural Set Divergence

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay
author_list.name: Saswat Meher

paper_content: This paper introduces GRAPHEDX, a neural estimator for Graph Edit Distance (GED).  It formulates GED as a quadratic assignment problem (QAP) considering diverse edit operation costs, and proposes neural set divergence surrogates to approximate it.  The model learns node and edge alignments to compute set divergences, enabling end-to-end training and efficient retrieval.

paper_title: GraphTrail: Translating GNN Predictions into Human-Interpretable Logical Rules
paper_content: GRAPHTRAIL is a novel global explainer for graph neural networks (GNNs).  It translates GNN predictions into human-interpretable logical rules by mining discriminative subgraph-level concepts and using symbolic regression to map these to boolean formulas.  Extensive experimentation demonstrates improved performance compared to existing global explainers in accuracy, interpretability, and robustness.

paper_title: How Far Can Fairness Constraints Help Recover From Biased Data?

author_list.affiliation_name: Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology, Delhi
author_list.name: mohit sharma

paper_content: This paper extends the work of Blum & Stangl (2019) on fair classification, demonstrating how fairness constraints can recover accurately fair classifiers even from extremely biased training data.  It generalizes their results to different fairness constraints, bias models, data distributions, and hypothesis classes, including cases with different types of label noise.  The paper further shows how these results apply to time-varying data bias and pipelines in machine learning.

paper_title: In-Context Principle Learning from Mistakes

author_list.affiliation_name: School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University

paper_content: The paper introduces LEAP, a prompting method for large language models (LLMs).  LEAP learns general principles from the LLM's mistakes on provided examples, rather than just the correct answers.  These learned principles are then used in conjunction with the original examples to improve the LLM's performance on unseen test inputs, without requiring additional training data.

paper_title: Iteratively Refined Early Interaction Alignment for Subgraph Matching based Graph Retrieval

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Dhirubhai Ambani Institute Of Information and Communication Technology
author_list.name: Ashwin Ramachandran

paper_content: This paper introduces IsoNet++, an improved graph retrieval model for subgraph isomorphism.  It leverages early interaction within a graph neural network (GNN) framework and iteratively refines node alignment between query and corpus graphs.  The key innovation is a multi-round alignment refinement strategy that progressively improves retrieval accuracy compared to existing methods.

paper_title: Latent Representation Matters: Human-like Sketches in One-shot Drawing Tasks

author_list.affiliation_name: School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University
author_list.name: Rishav Mukherji

author_list.affiliation_name: Birla Institute of Tchnology and Science - KK Birla Goa Campus
author_list.name: Aditya Agrawal

paper_content: This paper investigates whether representational inductive biases, effective in one-shot classification, can improve Latent Diffusion Models (LDMs) for one-shot drawing tasks.  It evaluates LDMs incorporating various regularizations (KL, vector quantization, classification, prototype-based, SimCLR, and Barlow), comparing their generated drawings to human-produced ones using metrics of recognizability and originality, as well as feature importance maps. The study aims to determine if LDMs can achieve near-human-like performance in one-shot drawing tasks by utilizing these representational inductive biases.

paper_title: Learning General Parameterized Policies for Infinite Horizon Average Reward Constrained MDPs via Primal-Dual Policy Gradient Algorithm
paper_content: This paper introduces a primal-dual policy gradient algorithm for learning parameterized policies in infinite horizon average reward constrained Markov Decision Processes (CMDPs).  It's the first to analyze regret and constraint violation for this class of problems with general policy parameterization.  The algorithm achieves sublinear regret and constraint violation bounds, improving upon existing results.

paper_title: Learning Mixtures of Unknown Causal Interventions

author_list.affiliation_name: Electrical Engineering & Computer Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

paper_content: The paper addresses the challenge of disentangling mixed interventional and observational data in linear Structural Equation Models (SEMs).  It presents an algorithm for learning the individual components of a mixture of unknown interventions, applicable to both "do" and "soft" interventions.  The method's sample complexity is shown to be inversely related to the intervention's impact, allowing for recovery of the causal graph up to its interventional Markov equivalence class.

paper_title: Linear Causal Representation Learning from Unknown Multi-node Interventions
paper_content: This paper investigates causal representation learning (CRL) with interventions on unknown, multiple nodes.  It establishes identifiability results for general latent causal models under both soft and hard interventions,  using linear transformations between latent and observed variables.  The results demonstrate that these conditions achieve the same performance as existing, more restrictive single-node intervention approaches.

paper_title: Long-Horizon Planning for Multi-Agent Robots in Partially Observable Environments
paper_content: This paper presents LLaMAR, an LM-based planner for multi-agent robots capable of long-horizon tasks in partially observable environments.  It addresses limitations of existing methods by incorporating a plan-act-correct-verify framework, enabling self-correction from action feedback without relying on oracles.  The authors evaluate LLaMAR against a new benchmark (MAP-THOR) and demonstrate improved performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

paper_title: MS-TIP: Imputation Aware Pedestrian Trajectory Prediction

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, Dhirubhai Ambani Institute Of Information and Communication Technology
author_list.name: Ishu Gupta

paper_content: This paper introduces MS-TIP, a novel approach for pedestrian trajectory prediction.  It addresses the inherent uncertainty in observed trajectories by simultaneously imputing missing data and predicting future trajectories.  The method leverages transformer networks with masked self-attention for imputation and multi-scale hypergraphs for interaction modeling, ultimately improving prediction accuracy compared to existing models.

paper_title: Mitigating Biases in Blackbox Feature Extractors for Image Classification Tasks
paper_content: This paper investigates mitigating biases in image classification models using pretrained, black-box feature extractors.  It focuses on the practical challenge of debiasing these models when the model weights are unavailable, proposing a clustering-based adaptive margin loss method.  The research explores how biases from the pretrained features affect downstream tasks and evaluates the effectiveness of the proposed strategy across various benchmarks.

paper_title: Mixture of Nested Experts: Adaptive Processing of Visual Tokens
paper_content: This paper introduces Mixture of Nested Experts (MoNE), a framework for optimizing the processing of visual tokens in Vision Transformer (ViT) models.  MoNE leverages a nested expert structure, allowing for dynamic allocation of computational resources based on token importance.  The approach achieves significant inference-time reductions while maintaining performance parity with baseline models.

paper_title: Near-Optimal Streaming Heavy-Tailed Statistical Estimation with Clipped SGD
paper_content: This paper investigates high-dimensional heavy-tailed statistical estimation in a streaming context, a problem significantly harder than the batch setting due to memory constraints.  It demonstrates that the ClippedSGD algorithm, when applied to stochastic convex optimization with heavy-tailed stochastic gradients, achieves near-optimal sub-Gaussian statistical rates under a finite second moment assumption on the stochastic gradient noise.  The analysis improves upon existing sub-optimal rates for ClippedSGD in this setting.

paper_title: OAK: Enriching Document Representations using Auxiliary Knowledge for Extreme Classification
paper_content: The paper introduces OAK, a novel framework for extreme classification (XC).  OAK leverages auxiliary knowledge (AK) associated with documents to enhance document representations and improve classification accuracy.  It aims to demonstrate the effectiveness of incorporating auxiliary data in XC tasks, contrasting with existing methods that do not utilize this information.

paper_title: On Online Experimentation without Device Identifiers

author_list.affiliation_name: Department of Computer Science, University of Massachusetts, Amherst
author_list.name: Madalina Fiterau

paper_content: This paper addresses the challenge of estimating causal effects in A/B testing when user identifiers are unavailable due to device fragmentation.  It proposes a variational inference method, HIFIVE, to estimate global average treatment effects (GATE) in this context, assuming interference only between devices shared by the same user.  The method leverages partial information about device-user pairings to achieve superior performance compared to existing methods while requiring fewer assumptions.

paper_title: Online Matrix Completion: A Collaborative Approach with Hott Items
paper_content: This paper addresses the online matrix completion problem, aiming to improve regret guarantees for greedy algorithms previously proposed.  It introduces two novel phased algorithms, PHASEDCLUSTERELIM and DETERMINANTELIM, leveraging a "hott items" assumption to achieve near-optimal per-user regret.  The algorithms build upon collaborative filtering techniques and effectively eliminate suboptimal items in phases to improve recommendations for multiple users.

paper_title: Optimal Algorithms for Online Convex Optimization with Adversarial Constraints

author_list.affiliation_name: Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai
author_list.name: Rahul Vaze

paper_content: This paper addresses the constrained online convex optimization (COCO) problem, seeking an online learning policy that minimizes regret and cumulative constraint violation (CCV).  The authors present a novel, efficient first-order policy achieving O(√T) regret and O(√T log T) CCV, a significant improvement over prior work.  Further, for strongly convex cost functions, improved regret bounds of O(log T) are derived while maintaining comparable CCV guarantees.

paper_title: Optimal Top-Two Method for Best Arm Identification and Fluid Analysis
paper_content: This paper introduces an optimal algorithm for identifying the best arm in a multi-armed bandit problem, with a focus on matching known lower bounds on sample complexity.  The algorithm dynamically adjusts the allocation of samples to different arms, using a fluid model that is shown to be asymptotically optimal as the desired accuracy level decreases.  The proposed algorithm leverages a specific index function to efficiently approach the optimal sampling proportions, leading to improved computational efficiency compared to existing plug-in methods.

paper_title: PIPER: Primitive-Informed Preference-based Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning via Hindsight Relabeling
paper_content: The paper introduces PIPER, a novel preference-based hierarchical reinforcement learning approach.  It aims to address non-stationarity in lower-level rewards and infeasible subgoal generation by learning a decoupled reward model using primitive-in-the-loop feedback.  This reward model is then used for hindsight relabeling of replay buffers to improve performance and sample efficiency in challenging sparse-reward tasks.

paper_title: PairNet: Training with Observed Pairs to Estimate Individual Treatment Effect
paper_content: This paper introduces PairNet, a novel method for estimating individual treatment effects (ITE).  Instead of relying on imputed pseudo-outcomes, PairNet minimizes losses on pairs of examples with similar covariates but different treatments, directly addressing the challenge of observational data bias.  Theoretical analysis and empirical comparisons across various benchmarks demonstrate PairNet's superior performance compared to existing methods.

paper_title: Policy Evaluation for Variance in Average Reward Reinforcement Learning
paper_content: This paper develops a temporal-difference (TD) algorithm for estimating the asymptotic variance of average reward reinforcement learning policies.  The algorithm is designed for safety-critical applications and leverages a linear stochastic approximation approach based on the Poisson equation.  Provable finite-time convergence rates are established for both tabular and linear function approximation settings.

paper_title: Predicting Ground State Properties: Constant Sample Complexity and Deep Learning Algorithms

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Science, Indian institute of science, Bangalore
author_list.name: Chiranjib Bhattacharyya

paper_content: This paper introduces two machine learning algorithms for predicting ground state properties of quantum systems with constant sample complexity, independent of system size.  The first algorithm requires prior knowledge of the property to be predicted, while the second, a deep neural network model, does not.  Both algorithms improve upon previous results by achieving optimal scaling with respect to prediction error.

paper_title: Provably Robust DPO: Aligning Language Models with Noisy Feedback
paper_content: This paper introduces a novel, provably robust method for aligning language models with noisy human feedback.  It focuses on the Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) algorithm, developing a new loss function (rDPO) that accounts for the noise in the preference data.  The authors provide theoretical guarantees on the sub-optimality gap of the rDPO policy compared to the optimal policy, demonstrated through experiments on sentiment generation and helpfulness datasets.

paper_title: Quantifying the Gain in Weak-to-Strong Generalization
paper_content: This paper develops a theoretical framework to quantify the performance improvement of a strong model (e.g., GPT-4) fine-tuned using labels from a weaker model (e.g., GPT-2).  It demonstrates that the gain in accuracy is directly proportional to the "misfit error" – the discrepancy between the strong model's predictions and the weak model's labels.  The authors validate their theoretical findings through empirical experiments on synthetic and real data.

paper_title: RanDumb: Random Representations Outperform Online Continually Learned Representations

author_list.affiliation_name: International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad
author_list.name: Shiven Sinha

author_list.affiliation_name: International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad
author_list.name: Ponnurangam Kumaraguru

paper_content: This paper investigates the effectiveness of representations learned through continual learning algorithms.  It argues that these representations are often inferior to simpler, pre-defined random transformations.  The authors introduce "RanDumb," a method using a random projection and linear classifier, which empirically outperforms state-of-the-art continual learning methods on several benchmarks.

paper_title: Representation Surgery: Theory and Practice of Affine Steering

author_list.affiliation_name: International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad
author_list.name: Shashwat Singh

author_list.affiliation_name: International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad
author_list.name: Ponnurangam Kumaraguru

paper_content: This paper develops a theoretical and empirical framework for "affine steering," a method of manipulating language model representations to mitigate undesirable behavior, such as generating toxic or biased text.  It derives optimal affine steering functions, maximizing least-squares error reduction while maintaining guardedness against unwanted concepts.  The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of these functions through experiments focusing on bias reduction and toxicity mitigation in language model outputs.

paper_title: Risk Estimation in a Markov Cost Process: Lower and Upper Bounds
paper_content: This paper investigates the sample complexity required to estimate risk measures (variance, VaR, CVaR) for the infinite-horizon discounted cost of a Markov cost process.  It establishes both lower and upper bounds for estimating these risk measures, demonstrating that Ω(1/ϵ<sup>2</sup>) samples are necessary and sufficient.  The findings extend to mean estimation and other risk measures satisfying certain continuity criteria.

paper_title: Safety through feedback in Constrained RL
paper_content: This paper introduces an algorithm, RLSF, for learning safe reinforcement learning policies.  It addresses the challenge of inferring cost functions in constrained RL settings when explicit cost functions are difficult or expensive to design.  The algorithm leverages trajectory-level feedback from a human evaluator and employs a novelty-based sampling mechanism to effectively collect feedback.

paper_title: Sample Complexity of Interventional Causal Representation Learning
paper_content: This paper analyzes the sample complexity of interventional causal representation learning (CRL) in finite-sample settings.  It establishes probabilistic guarantees for recovering latent variables and causal structures, focusing on general latent causal models, stochastic interventions, and linear transformations.  The results explicitly characterize the dependence of sample complexity on the dimensions of latent and observed spaces, improving upon existing asymptotic guarantees.

paper_title: Sample-Efficient Constrained Reinforcement Learning with General Parameterization
paper_content: This paper proposes a new algorithm, PD-ANPG, for constrained reinforcement learning (CMDP) with general policy parameterization.  The goal is to maximize expected discounted rewards while ensuring expected discounted costs remain above a threshold.  PD-ANPG achieves a sample complexity of  O˜((1 − γ)−7ϵ−2), improving upon the state-of-the-art for general parameterization and closing the gap with theoretical lower bounds.

paper_title: Submodular framework for structured-sparse optimal transport
paper_content: This paper proposes novel methods for learning sparse optimal transport (OT) plans, focusing on unbalanced OT (UOT).  It formulates the problem as maximizing a weakly submodular function over a matroid constraint, leading to efficient gradient-based greedy algorithms.  The algorithms are shown to yield sparse, interpretable solutions, applicable to various machine learning tasks.

paper_title: TFS-NeRF: Template-Free NeRF for Semantic 3D Reconstruction of Dynamic Scene

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Dhirubhai Ambani Institute Of Information and Communication Technology
author_list.name: Biplab Banerjee

paper_content: This paper introduces TFS-NeRF, a new template-free NeRF model for reconstructing dynamic scenes from sparse or single-view RGB videos.  It aims to efficiently reconstruct semantically separable geometries of multiple interacting entities, focusing on time-efficiency and handling interactions between arbitrary deformable objects.  The method leverages an Invertible Neural Network to predict Linear Blend Skinning weights, improving training efficiency and enabling accurate reconstruction of both deformable and non-deformable objects.

paper_title: Tandem Transformers for Inference Efficient LLMs
paper_content: This paper introduces Tandem Transformers, a novel architecture for large language models (LLMs) aiming to improve inference speed without sacrificing accuracy.  The architecture combines a small, autoregressive model with a larger model that processes tokens in blocks, enhancing the smaller model's performance by leveraging the larger model's richer representations.  The goal is to decouple the capacity requirements for natural language understanding and generation, enabling more efficient LLMs.

paper_title: Testing the Feasibility of Linear Programs with Bandit Feedback
paper_content: This paper investigates the feasibility of linear programs (LPs) using bandit feedback.  It develops a new test to determine if a given LP is feasible, characterized by the costs of this testing process.  The proposed test is shown to be reliable and efficient, with sample costs scaling proportionally to d²/Γ², where d is the dimension and Γ is the signal level.

paper_title: Text2CAD: Generating Sequential CAD Designs from Beginner-to-Expert Level Text Prompts

author_list.affiliation_name: BITS Pilani, Birla Institute of Technology and Science
author_list.name: Sk Aziz Ali

paper_content: This paper introduces Text2CAD, a novel AI framework for generating parametric CAD models from text prompts.  The framework leverages a dataset annotated with diverse text descriptions, ranging from basic to detailed, to train an autoregressive transformer network for generating CAD design sequences.  The goal is to create a user-friendly AI-assisted CAD design tool for users of all skill levels.

paper_title: The WMDP Benchmark: Measuring and Reducing Malicious Use with Unlearning

author_list.affiliation_name: International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad
author_list.name: Ponnurangam Kumaraguru

author_list.affiliation_name: Department of Computer Science, University of Toronto
author_list.name: Jimmy Ba

paper_content: This paper introduces the WMDP benchmark, a dataset of 3,668 multiple-choice questions designed to measure hazardous knowledge in biosecurity, cybersecurity, and chemical security within large language models (LLMs).  The paper also presents RMU, a novel unlearning method, aiming to reduce a model's performance on WMDP while preserving general capabilities.  The ultimate goal is to provide a publicly available benchmark for evaluating and reducing the potential malicious use of LLMs.

paper_title: Time-Reversal Provides Unsupervised Feedback to LLMs
paper_content: This paper introduces Time-Reversed Language Models (TRLMs) to provide unsupervised feedback for large language models (LLMs).  TRLMs operate in the reverse direction of time, scoring and generating queries given responses.  The authors demonstrate improvements in various downstream tasks, including re-ranking answers, citation generation, retrieval, and improving safety filters, highlighting the benefits of reverse-direction scoring and generation.

paper_title: Tiny Time Mixers (TTMs): Fast Pre-trained Models for Enhanced Zero/Few-Shot Forecasting of Multivariate Time Series
paper_content: This paper introduces Tiny Time Mixers (TTMs), a lightweight pre-trained model for efficient zero/few-shot forecasting of multivariate time series.  TTM leverages a compact architecture and novel techniques for handling diverse datasets, achieving superior performance compared to existing large models while requiring significantly fewer computational resources.  The model is designed for practical use in resource-constrained environments.

paper_title: Total Variation Distance Meets Probabilistic Inference
paper_content: This paper establishes a novel connection between estimating total variation (TV) distance and probabilistic inference in directed graphical models.  Specifically, it presents a polynomial-time randomized approximation scheme (FPRAS) for approximating TV distances between distributions defined on Bayes nets with small treewidth.  This method leverages probabilistic inference algorithms and a new concept of partial couplings.

paper_title: Transfer Learning for Latent Variable Network Models
paper_content: This paper introduces a transfer learning algorithm for estimating latent variable network models.  It focuses on estimating a target network's edge probability matrix using data from a similar source network, even when only a small portion of the target network is observed.  The algorithm leverages a graph distance metric to identify relationships between the source and target networks, achieving an efficient, non-parametric estimation method with vanishing error under specific conditions.

paper_title: UGC: Universal Graph Coarsening
paper_content: This paper introduces Universal Graph Coarsening (UGC), a novel framework for reducing large graphs while preserving crucial information.  Crucially, UGC is designed to handle both homophilic and heterophilic datasets, a significant advancement over existing methods.  The approach leverages node attributes and the graph's adjacency information, resulting in a linear time complexity and superior performance on benchmark datasets compared to existing methods.

paper_title: Unsupervised Parameter-free Simplicial Representation Learning with Scattering Transforms
paper_content: This paper introduces a novel, parameter-free simplicial scattering network (SSN) for learning representations from simplicial complex data.  SSN extracts task-agnostic features by leveraging scattering transforms, inspired by geometric scattering, and avoids the training complexity and label dependence of existing simplicial neural networks.  The model demonstrates improved performance and efficiency compared to existing methods on various tasks, including node and graph classification, highlighting its effectiveness in capturing higher-order interactions within the data.

paper_title: WISER: Weak Supervision and Supervised Representation Learning to Improve Drug Response Prediction in Cancer

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Science, Indian institute of science, Bangalore
author_list.name: Kumar Shubham

author_list.affiliation_name: Indian Institute of Science, Indian institute of science, Bangalore
author_list.name: Prathosh AP

paper_content: This paper proposes a novel method, WISER, to improve drug response prediction in cancer patients.  It leverages supervised representation learning to create domain-invariant representations of genomic data, and employs weak supervision techniques with a subset selection strategy to enhance prediction accuracy.  The method combines labeled cell line data with unlabeled patient data, improving upon existing approaches by incorporating drug response information and carefully selecting pseudo-labeled patient data for training.

paper_title: Weakly Convex Regularisers for Inverse Problems: Convergence of Critical Points and Primal-Dual Optimisation
paper_content: This paper investigates convergent regularisation for inverse problems, focusing on critical points rather than global minimisers.  It develops a generalized framework for proving convergence using weakly convex regularisers, demonstrating convergence of primal-dual hybrid gradient methods.  Finally, the authors apply their theory to learned regularisation, proving results for input weakly convex neural networks (IWCNNs) along with empirical validations for CT reconstruction.
